• *Current Forms Usage and Integration Plans:* Manju, Pavan Kumar Ainampudi, and Ashajyoti from the Micron team, along with Mayank, Vijay Kumar, and Anurag from the AM Forms team, discussed the current use of AEM forms, the integration with Marketo and Salesforce, and upcoming plans to migrate to Microsoft Dynamics 365 and expand form usage for events and lead generation.
    ◦ *Existing Forms and Integrations:* Manju explained that Micron currently uses a small number of forms for registration, contact, and technical sales, with data initially routed to Salesforce and then synced to Marketo. The team is consolidating forms and planning to migrate CRM systems from Salesforce to Microsoft Dynamics 365, which is expected to improve two-way sync capabilities.
    ◦ *Event and Campaign Use Cases:* The team uses Marketo landing pages for event registrations and aims to unify the experience on <http://micron.com|micron.com> for consistency. Events such as CES and expos require extensive form usage to capture leads and contacts from partners and customers.
    ◦ *Marketo Campaigns and Retargeting:* Manju confirmed that Marketo campaigns are leveraged for retargeting different customer segments using smart lists, and that these are a core part of their marketing automation strategy.
    ◦ *Future Roadmap and Expansion:* While the primary focus remains on lead generation and event forms, Pavan Kumar Ainampudi mentioned that additional use cases are under discussion for the future, though details are still being finalized.
• *Migration from Foundation to Core Components:* Pradeep, Anurag, and Vijay Kumar discussed the migration strategy from foundation components to core components for forms, including technical considerations, migration utilities, and the impact on styling and business logic.
    ◦ *Migration Utility Limitations:* Anurag clarified that the current migration utility can migrate content but not business logic or custom code, so teams should evaluate the complexity of their forms before migrating.
    ◦ *Styling and Customization Differences:* Pradeep asked about style system compatibility, and Anurag explained that team representation and styling may differ between foundation and core components, suggesting a separate discussion with the engineering lead for migration specifics.
    ◦ *Headless and External Application Support:* Vijay Kumar and Pradeep discussed embedding forms in external applications using headless capabilities, with Vijay confirming that both core components and edge delivery forms support headless integration for frameworks like React and Angular.
    ◦ *Migration Assessment and Next Steps:* Mayank and Pradeep agreed to assess the time and effort required to migrate approximately 40 forms, with Pradeep offering to provide access to development instances and custom JS/CSS files for review by the AM Forms team.
• *Forms Experience Builder and Rule Editor Challenges:* Ashajyoti presented several challenges encountered with the Forms Experience Builder, particularly with the rule editor’s validation logic, editing capabilities, and navigation after submission, prompting the AM Forms team to request form samples for debugging.
    ◦ *Rule Editor Validation Issues:* Ashajyoti described intermittent problems where the rule editor fails to validate or allow editing of rules, especially when creating custom validation logic for form fields.
    ◦ *Navigation and Post-Submission Actions:* Ashajyoti noted that navigation after form submission is limited when forms are embedded via iframes, requiring custom code to achieve desired redirection, and suggested enhancements for more seamless navigation handling.
    ◦ *Custom JS for Field Value Handling:* Ashajyoti explained the need to write custom JavaScript to update DOM values for input fields, as the foundation components do not automatically update the value attribute, leading to additional development overhead.
    ◦ *Debugging and Next Steps:* The AM Forms team requested that Ashajyoti share problematic forms and related code samples to facilitate debugging and provide targeted recommendations, with follow-up actions to review and address the highlighted issues.
• *Headless Forms Integration and Documentation:* Arneh, Mayank, and Pavan Kumar Ainampudi discussed the availability of headless integration for forms, sharing documentation and starter kits for React and Angular, and confirming that Marketo integration features are supported in headless scenarios.
    ◦ *Headless Integration Capabilities:* Mayank and Vijay Kumar confirmed that both core components and edge delivery forms support headless integration, allowing forms to be embedded in external applications using JSON output and starter kits for React and Angular.
    ◦ *Marketo Integration in Headless Mode:* Pavan Kumar Ainampudi asked if Marketo integration features are available in headless mode, and Mayank confirmed that submission endpoints and integration logic remain consistent regardless of the rendering approach.
    ◦ *Documentation and Resources:* Arneh provided links to developer documentation and a code playground for headless forms integration, ensuring the Micron team has resources to reference after the meeting.

Meeting notes:
• *Repository Structure and Code Walkthrough:* Sakshi provided an overview of the restructured repository for cloud deployment, explaining the separation between immutable and mutable content, and highlighted how OSGI configurations, custom components, and client libraries are managed, with input and clarifying questions from Randy Reisling and others.
    ◦ *Repository Modularization:* Sakshi explained that the repository is divided into immutable content (custom components, client libraries, developer activities) and mutable content (author activities, templates, sample content), allowing for selective inclusion in CI/CD pipelines.
    ◦ *OSGI Configuration Management:* Sakshi described how OSGI configurations are managed in the UI.config directory, with separate files for different environments (author, publish), and emphasized the use of environment variables for sensitive data like client secrets.
    ◦ *Custom Functions and Client Libraries:* Sakshi demonstrated how JavaScript functions can be added to client libraries, making them available in the rule editor UI for form authors, and provided an example of a custom function for use in forms.
    ◦ *Pipeline and Branch Setup:* Sakshi showed the setup of development branches and pipelines, explaining how different branches can be targeted for deployments and how full stack and frontend pipelines are configured.
• *Azure Email Integration and OAuth Configuration:* Abhishek and Sakshi, with support from Sudhanshu and Chad, guided Randy Reisling and the team through the process of configuring Azure OAuth for email integration, including setting up Azure Active Directory, registering applications, defining scopes, and managing secrets and tokens.
    ◦ *Azure App Registration and Scopes:* Abhishek outlined the steps for registering an application in Azure Active Directory, specifying required scopes (SMTP.Send, openid, offline_access), and setting up redirect URLs for OAuth authentication.
    ◦ *Secret and Token Management:* The team discussed how to generate and store client secrets and refresh tokens, with Abhishek providing a Java utility and video tutorial to help generate and validate tokens, and Sakshi clarifying the use of environment variables for secure storage.
    ◦ *Configuration in Cloud Manager:* Randy, with guidance from Sakshi and Abhishek, was walked through adding the necessary configuration variables in Cloud Manager, including naming conventions and the distinction between client secret and refresh token.
    ◦ *Troubleshooting Token Generation:* Chad and Abhishek collaborated to resolve issues with generating the refresh token, identifying problems with URL formatting (removal of angular braces) and scope definitions, and confirming the correct use of client secret values.
    ◦ *Token Expiry and Usage:* Abhishek explained that refresh tokens generally do not expire if used regularly, but will expire after 90 days of inactivity or if password or policy changes occur.
• *Advanced Networking and Environment Region Configuration:* Sudhanshu, Sakshi, and Abhishek assisted Randy Reisling and Chad in understanding and configuring advanced networking in Cloud Manager, focusing on opening SMTP ports, selecting appropriate regions (Canada vs. US), and managing environment deletion and recreation to meet GDPR and organizational requirements.
    ◦ *Advanced Networking Purpose:* Sudhanshu clarified that advanced networking is required to open ports beyond HTTP/HTTPS, such as SMTP for email and specific ports for Azure SQL Server connections.
    ◦ *Region Selection and GDPR Concerns:* Randy and Chad raised concerns about environment region (Canada vs. US) due to GDPR and German Work Council requirements, with Sakshi and Sudhanshu confirming that environments can be recreated in the desired region and that region selection impacts available networking options.
    ◦ *Environment Deletion and Recreation:* The team discussed the process for deleting and recreating dev and prod environments to enable region selection, with Sakshi advising written consent for prod deletion and confirming that repositories and code can be reused.
    ◦ *Permission and Role Requirements:* The group reviewed necessary permissions (business owner, deployment manager) for advanced networking configuration, troubleshooting access issues and confirming roles in the admin console.
    ◦ *Flexible Port Egress Setup:* Attempts were made to configure flexible port egress, with troubleshooting around grayed-out options, deletion of existing configurations, and documentation references for correct setup.
• *Dynamic Dropdown Population and Custom Functions in Forms:* Sakshi demonstrated the implementation of dynamic dropdown population in forms using custom JavaScript functions, addressing a previously open support ticket and showing how client libraries and pipelines are used to deploy these functions.
    ◦ *Custom Function Implementation:* Sakshi showed a JavaScript function that extracts property values from a JSON array for use in dropdowns, explaining how it can be invoked via event payloads or hardcoded data.
    ◦ *Client Library Deployment:* The process for adding custom functions to client libraries and making them available in the rule editor was demonstrated, including the use of annotations and pipeline deployment.
    ◦ *Integration with Data Sources:* Sakshi explained that if a service returns an array of strings (e.g., from SQL Server), it can be directly assigned to the dropdown enum, whereas more complex data (e.g., from SharePoint) may require transformation.

• *URL Rewriting Issue:* Customer reported embedded form failures caused by model.json paths not being rewritten properly through Cloudflare and AEM filters.
• *Cloudflare Routing Rules:* Andy described how Cloudflare is configured to route requests with specific prefixes (such as /aem-form) to the appropriate AEM instance based on the environment (dev, QA, prod), ensuring that requests are directed correctly depending on the deployment stage.
• *Embed Logic Review:* Engineering reviewed loadAdaptiveForm logic and confirmed script sequencing follows Adobe’s guidance but fails for core components.
• *Core-Component Behavior:* Issue occurs only in core components; foundation components load correctly due to differing callback handling.
• *Blocker Confirmation:* Customer confirmed all current forms are blocked from UAT due to unresolved routing and model.json failures.
• *Form Conversion Progress:* Three forms have passed development testing successfully; QA and UAT are on hold until the routing issue is fixed.

Meeting notes:
• *Azure SQL Database Integration and Networking Configuration:* Shraddha, Sakshi, Randy, and Chad Roberts discussed the technical requirements and steps for connecting AEM to Azure SQL Database, focusing on advanced networking configurations, egress settings, and firewall rules, with action items assigned to both teams for further investigation and setup.
    ◦ *Egress Configuration Requirements:* The team reviewed the need for dedicated egress to obtain a static IP address for whitelisting in Azure, and discussed the limitations of flexible port egress, which is required for SMTP but does not provide a fixed IP range. Sakshi and Shraddha agreed to investigate if both dedicated and flexible egress can be enabled simultaneously or if domain whitelisting is possible.
    ◦ *Firewall and Connectivity Settings:* Shraddha guided Randy through the Azure portal to review current firewall rules and connectivity settings, confirming that only IP addresses (not domains) can be whitelisted, and highlighted the need to switch the connectivity mode to 'proxy' for AEM integration.
    ◦ *Direct Database Creation and Access:* Chad Roberts clarified that their current setup involves direct SQL DB creation without a server layer, which complicates networking configuration. The group agreed to explore direct connection options and document the process, as current integrations rely on a server intermediary.
    ◦ *Action Items and Next Steps:* Shraddha and Sakshi will investigate the feasibility of switching from flexible to dedicated egress and the implications for SMTP/email integration, while Chad and Randy are tasked with setting up secret variables and adjusting connectivity settings in Azure and AEM. Updates will be shared via email and Teams.
• *Environment Variable and Secret Management in AEM:* Sakshi and Randy discussed best practices for managing sensitive credentials in AEM, recommending the use of environment variables for secrets such as SMTP tokens and database passwords, and provided guidance on configuring these in Cloud Manager.
    ◦ *Storing Secrets Securely:* Sakshi advised Randy to revert storing SMTP credentials directly in the repository and instead configure them as environment variables in Cloud Manager, ensuring restricted access and improved security.
    ◦ *Environment Variable Usage:* The team clarified that environment variables should be used for secrets in both development and production environments, and Sakshi demonstrated how these variables are referenced in configuration files and picked up by AEM during deployment.
    ◦ *Configuration File Management:* Sakshi explained that configuration changes should be made in the code repository and deployed via the pipeline, rather than directly in the UI, to ensure consistency across local and cloud environments.
• *AEM Deployment Workflow and Pipeline Process:* Randy, Sakshi, and Harman discussed the end-to-end process for deploying code changes from local development to the AEM cloud environment, including Maven builds, repository management, and pipeline execution.
    ◦ *Local Development and Build:* The group reviewed the use of Maven (MVN clean install) for building local changes, with Sakshi and Harman providing troubleshooting steps for Java version management and build errors.
    ◦ *Repository and Pipeline Usage:* Sakshi explained that after committing changes to the cloud repository, the deployment pipeline must be run to push updates to the development, staging, or production environments, clarifying the distinction between non-production and production pipelines.
    ◦ *Role Assignments and Access:* Randy was guided through assigning developer roles to Harman and Shraddha in AEM, with Sakshi specifying the minimum required permissions and Harman providing additional tips for user management.
• *AEM Workflow and Form Integration Progress:* Harman updated the team on the status of workflow and form integration in the AEM dev environment, describing a test workflow and form setup, and outlined plans for further development once foundational integrations are complete.
    ◦ *Test Workflow Implementation:* Harman described a test workflow with two steps—task assignment and Java code execution—linked to a form submission, and confirmed that logs are available in Splunk for monitoring.
    ◦ *Next Steps for Forms:* The team agreed to revisit form and workflow development after resolving the SQL and email integrations, with Harman encouraging Randy to explore the current setup and share questions for future sessions.
• *Documentation, Onboarding, and User Role Clarification:* Randy raised concerns about the complexity of AEM documentation and the lack of clear onboarding materials, prompting Harman to share relevant links and offer to address specific queries via email or chat.
    ◦ *Documentation Gaps and Orientation Needs:* Randy expressed difficulty understanding user roles, permissions, and deployment steps due to fragmented documentation, and suggested that an orientation session would have been beneficial at project start.
    ◦ *Support for User Role Setup:* Harman provided documentation links and offered to answer specific questions about user roles, permissions, and workflow setup, encouraging the team to share issues for targeted assistance.
Follow-up tasks:
• *Azure SQL and Email Integration Networking:* Verify if both dedicated and flexible egress can be configured simultaneously for Azure SQL and email integration, or if domain whitelisting is possible for direct database connections without SQL Server. (Speaker 1)
• *Cloud Manager Secret Variable Setup:* Set up the secret variable for Azure SQL database connection in Cloud Manager environment variables. (Chad Roberts)
• *Azure SQL Connectivity Configuration:* Update Azure SQL connectivity settings to use proxy connections as required for AEM integration. (Chad Roberts)
• *SMTP Credentials Security:* Revert SMTP password and authentication token from repository to environment secrets and configure them as restricted variables. (Randy)
• *Sample Code Sharing for SQL DB Connection:* Share sample code or details on how the current applications are interacting with Azure SQL DB directly (outside of AEM) to assist integration efforts. (Randy)
• *Developer Access Provisioning:* Provide Harman and Shraddha with developer roles and environment access in AEM as requested. (Randy)
• *Advanced Networking Configuration Exploration:* Explore and update the advanced networking configuration in Cloud Manager to support port forwarding for Azure SQL (port 1433) and document any required changes. (Speaker 1)
• *Documentation Improvement Request:* Document and share a straightforward step-by-step guide for deploying changes from local development to cloud environments, including pipeline usage and user role setup. (Randy)
• *Workflow and Form Use Case Progress:* Continue building and documenting the first form and workflow as a template for future use cases, ensuring progress is tracked and communicated to the team. (Harman)

Meeting notes:
• *Current Forms Environment and Integration Challenges:* Tony J Fenner, Stephen, Brad R Tuckner, and John described the current forms landscape at Mayo Clinic, highlighting the use of multiple platforms (AEM forms, fillable PDFs, HTML forms), the lack of integration with Epic, and the need for a more unified, user-friendly, and efficient forms management system.
    ◦ *Forms Platform Fragmentation:* Stephen and Tony J Fenner explained that Mayo Clinic currently uses three main platforms for forms: AEM forms (about 70 forms), fillable PDFs (hundreds to thousands), and HTML forms (over 5,000), with each platform serving different levels of form complexity. This fragmentation leads to inefficiencies and inconsistent user experiences.
    ◦ *Epic Integration Limitations:* Tony J Fenner and Stephen discussed that the current on-prem solution has minimal clinical integration, with forms accessed via links from Epic but lacking embedded workflows or patient context transfer. The team expressed a desire for tighter integration, such as launching forms within Epic with pre-filled patient and provider data.
    ◦ *User Experience Goals:* John and Stephen emphasized the need for a modern, guided, and simple user experience for form completion, drawing analogies to TurboTax, where users are guided through a process and the system generates the required official documents at the end.
    ◦ *Governance and Rogue Solutions:* Brad R Tuckner highlighted the importance of a managed forms program to maintain high standards and consistency, noting that staff have begun adopting less expensive, unofficial solutions, which undermines governance and increases urgency for modernization.
• *Modernization Strategy and Platform Consolidation:* Arun, Stephen, John, and Brad R Tuckner discussed strategies for consolidating forms onto a single platform (AEM forms), prioritizing high-value use cases, and leveraging reusable components to improve scalability, cost-effectiveness, and maintainability.
    ◦ *Platform Consolidation Benefits:* Arun described the advantages of consolidating all forms (marketing, clinical, administrative) onto AEM forms, including the ability to manage multiple use cases, separate or combine programs as needed, and leverage features like reusable form fragments and templates.
    ◦ *Reusable Components and Templates:* Arun and John discussed the use of reusable form fragments and templates within AEM forms, which would allow the team to create modular, maintainable forms and provide a consistent user experience across different use cases.
    ◦ *Migration Prioritization:* John and Stephen suggested starting the modernization effort with high-impact use cases, such as patient consent and authorization forms, to demonstrate value and build momentum for broader migration.
    ◦ *Cost and Pricing Considerations:* Stephen and John raised concerns about per-submission pricing for simple forms, emphasizing the need for affordable solutions, especially for high-volume, low-complexity forms, and discussed the possibility of using different SKUs or negotiating discounts.
• *Technical Requirements and Data Integration:* Sakshi, Tony J Fenner, and John explored technical requirements for data handling, including the use of XML and JSON, barcode integration for lab orders, and the need for flexible data export and workflow capabilities.
    ◦ *XML and JSON Data Handling:* Sakshi asked about the transition from XML to JSON for data export; Tony J Fenner clarified that while XML is currently used for certain integrations (e.g., supply chain), the team is open to adopting JSON for modernization, provided legacy integrations are maintained.
    ◦ *Barcode and Order Matching:* Tony J Fenner described the workflow for lab orders, where a fillable PDF is printed and included with samples; the ideal future state would embed an ID or barcode in the document to enable automated lookup and eliminate manual data entry.
    ◦ *Workflow and Approval Processes:* Tony J Fenner explained that some forms, such as supply chain requests, involve approval workflows with human-in-the-loop steps, managed via J2EE workflows in the current on-prem environment.
• *Use Case Identification and Next Steps:* Arun, Tony J Fenner, John, and Stephen agreed to focus initial modernization efforts on high-value forms (e.g., patient consent and authorization), requested sample forms for further analysis, and coordinated scheduling for the next meeting to discuss migration paths and technical demonstrations.
    ◦ *Sample Forms for Analysis:* Arun requested URLs or examples of representative forms (especially consent and authorization forms) to tailor future discussions and demonstrations; Tony J Fenner agreed to provide these samples.
    ◦ *Meeting Scheduling:* The group discussed scheduling the next session to allow time for preparation and to accommodate holidays, ultimately agreeing to coordinate with Kelly to find a suitable date, with Tony J Fenner identified as a required participant.
    ◦ *Focus on High-Impact Use Cases:* John and Stephen reiterated the strategy of starting with a narrow, high-value use case (e.g., consents and authorizations) to demonstrate ROI and build a foundation for broader modernization.
• *Storefront and End-User Access Improvements:* Stephen presented the vision for a unified forms storefront, where users can access all forms and publications through a single interface, regardless of underlying technology, to streamline workflows and reduce confusion.
    ◦ *Unified Catalog Access:* Stephen described the goal of providing a single searchable catalog for all forms and publications, allowing users to access any item without navigating multiple platforms or contexts.
    ◦ *Consistent User Pathways:* The team discussed the importance of ensuring that users are not forced into different workflows based on form complexity or platform, aiming for a seamless experience across the entire forms library.
Follow-up tasks:
• *Sample Forms for Modernization Use Cases:* Share a few sample URLs of the simpler forms (e.g., consent and authorization forms) that will serve as initial use cases for modernization to help tailor future discussions and demos. (Tony J Fenner)
• *Next Meeting Scheduling:* Coordinate with Kelly to find a suitable date and time for the next meeting, ensuring Tony's required attendance and accommodating other key participants' schedules. (the team)
• *Storefront Context Sharing:* Package and send screenshots or a PDF of the next iteration of the storefront to provide context for the universal forms environment discussion. (Stephen)

Abbott is encountering multiple conversion issues, as detailed in <https://wiki.corp.adobe.com/display/lc/PDF+Generator+Support+for+Office+2021+and+Acrobat+DC|this wiki page>
, during their environment upgrade from *Windows Server 2016 + Office 2016 + Acrobat Classic* to *Windows Server 2022 + Office 2021 + Acrobat DC*.
As outlined in the wiki, workarounds are available for the reported issues, and Abbott has agreed to adopt the approach of running the AEM server interactively (from the command line).
Previously, the customer required an exception approval to operate the server in command-line mode due to security restrictions. However, in their recent update, Abbott confirmed that this exception approval is no longer required.

We have discussed the following four options with the customer:
1. *Run server in command-line mode* – The customer has tried this approach and is currently performing testing in their environment. They have made progress with this approach and are continuing their validation to complete testing.
2. *Multi-threaded support with single user* – As mentioned in the <https://wiki.corp.adobe.com/display/lc/Action+Plan+for+Office+to+PDF+Conversions+and+PDF+Generator+Roadmap|PDF Generator Roadmap>, we implemented and shared update about solution that enables multi-threaded support with a single user while running the server as a service. This update was shared with the customer, and they provided positive feedback and confirmed their readiness. With this solution, Word and Excel conversions support multi-threaded execution, whereas PowerPoint remains single-threaded. The customer indicated a need for PowerPoint multi-threaded conversions as well for certain use cases. To achieve this, they plan to run the server in command-line mode(with multi-threaded conversion by a single user for Excel).
3. *Abbott application improvements* – Abbott shared their application code for evaluation, and we provided recommendations to improve throughput. However, at this stage, the customer is not planning to implement any changes and intends to revisit this after resolving the current issues.
4. *Long-term plans for Office conversions* – Abbott has requested Adobe to share its long-term roadmap and strategy for Office conversions.

• *Migration from Foundation to Core Component Based Forms:* Sakshi and Amit explained the process and results of migrating the large JSON-based foundation component form to a core component based form, highlighting performance improvements, technical changes, and the implications for Vijay and the team.
    ◦ *Migration Process Overview:* Sakshi described converting the provided JSON foundation component form, which contained approximately 9,100 fields across 9 tables, into a core component based form, and then scaling it up to 37,000 fields to test performance and tab navigation.
    ◦ *Performance Comparison:* The team observed that while the initial render time for the core component based form was high (around 4 minutes for 37,000 fields), tab navigation was significantly faster compared to the foundation component based form.
    ◦ *Technical Adjustments:* Due to the lack of a table component in core components, Sakshi explained that tables were represented using panels, and formatting or table-like appearance would need to be achieved through CSS or by developing a custom table component.
    ◦ *Coexistence of Form Types:* Sakshi clarified that foundation component based forms and core component based forms can coexist within the same AEM infrastructure, and migrating one form does not impact others.
• *React-Based Headless Form Rendering:* Amit demonstrated rendering the migrated core component form using a React-based headless approach, detailing the technical setup, performance benefits, and deployment considerations for Vijay and the team.
    ◦ *React Rendering Setup:* Amit showcased the use of a custom React application that fetches JSON from the core component and renders it using a custom hook, with the setup available via code sandbox and downloadable packages.
    ◦ *Performance Metrics:* Sakshi and Amit reported that the React-based rendering significantly reduced the initial render time to under a minute for 37,000 fields, with tab switching occurring almost instantaneously.
    ◦ *Deployment and Infrastructure:* Sakshi and Amit explained that deploying the React component requires embedding it within a site page, and that the React-based approach does not require changes to the existing AEM authoring infrastructure, but does require a React client library.

    ◦ *Theming Consistency:* Sakshi and Amit confirmed that core component based forms and vanilla React forms share the same HTML structure, allowing the same CSS themes to be applied to both, provided the official library is used.
    ◦ *Table Representation:* Sakshi explained that, in the absence of a table component in core components, tables are represented as panels, and achieving a table-like appearance requires custom CSS and potentially additional JavaScript.

• *Overview of Adobe AEM Forms Value Proposition:* Melissa, Mark, and Jared from Adobe provided Sunil, Williams-VZ, Ani, Kiran, and the Verizon team with a comprehensive overview of the value proposition, features, and differentiators of Adobe AEM Forms, focusing on interactive communications, integration, compliance, and collaboration capabilities.
• *Interactive Communications Features:* Melissa recapped the core features of AEM Forms’ interactive communications, highlighting a single source of truth, centralized management, business rule-driven workflows, automation to reduce manual effort and errors, flexible data integration, and governance with reusable templates and collaboration between IT and business users.
• *Scalability and Omnichannel Delivery:* Melissa explained that AEM Forms enables scalable document processing, supporting both on-demand and batch operations at high volume, and facilitates omnichannel experiences by allowing content deployment across digital and print channels with reusable templates and content fragments.
• *Integration and Compliance:* The team emphasized AEM Forms’ flexibility in integrating disparate data sources and maintaining compliance, with features such as pre-approved content, locked templates, and collaborative workflows that ensure governance and regulatory adherence.
• *Differentiators and Future Capabilities:* Melissa and Arun discussed differentiators such as empowering business users, upcoming Gen AI authoring (currently in early access), tight integration with Adobe Experience Cloud, and the platform’s ability to address both output and input use cases, providing a unified solution for future needs.
• *Comparison of On-Premise and Cloud Service Offerings:* Jared, Arun, and Melissa detailed the differences between Adobe AEM Forms’ on-premise and cloud service models for the Verizon team, covering entitlements, technical capabilities, user management, infrastructure, and the implications for AI features and integration.
• *On-Premise Model Details:* Jared outlined the on-premise proposal, which includes up to 360 million renditions per year, AEM Forms Portal, reader extensions, adaptive forms, interactive communications, integrations, and media library, with clarification from Arun that the charging model is based solely on renditions, not individual modules.
• *Cloud Service Model Details:* Jared described the cloud service offering, which also supports 360 million renditions per year but adds Cloud Manager for environment management, automated provisioning of production, stage, and dev environments, and Adobe-managed compliance and security for infrastructure.
• *User and Environment Management:* Arun clarified that on-premise allows unlimited local installations of the Forms Designer, while the cloud version includes both standalone and integrated designer tools with upcoming versioning support; disaster recovery and redundancy are managed by the customer on-premise but handled by Adobe in the cloud.
• *AI and Innovation Availability:* Todd, Arun, and Melissa explained that AI-driven features, such as Gen AI authoring and prompt-based template generation, are exclusive to the cloud service, with ongoing innovation and integration with other Adobe cloud solutions, while on-premise does not support these AI capabilities.
• *Technical Clarifications on Renditions, Templates, and Integration:* Sunil, Ani, Williams-VZ, and Arun engaged in a detailed technical discussion to clarify the definition of renditions, template management, asset handling, and integration options for both on-premise and cloud deployments.
• *Definition and Counting of Renditions:* Arun confirmed that a rendition is defined as a single generated document (not per page), regardless of whether it is a bill, letter, or other template, and applies to both digital and print outputs; repeated retrievals of the same stored document do not count as additional renditions if the document is not regenerated.
• *Template and Asset Management:* The team discussed that the Forms Designer is used to create templates, which are then uploaded to AEM; the Media Library is used for managing in-house assets such as icons and logos, and is not an external stock library, with asset search and management available within the repository.
• *Feature Inclusion and Additional Purchases:* Arun clarified that all listed features (e.g., Forms Portal, Designer, Media Library) are included in the base package, and the only charge is for the number of renditions; there is no need to purchase additional modules for the described use cases.
• *Integration and Batch Processing:* Arun explained that both API and batch processing are supported: on-premise uses local infrastructure for batch data and output, while the cloud version uses Azure Blob storage; both models support synchronous and batch operations, with the cloud offering additional integration benefits for multi-solution architectures.
• *Next Steps and Internal Decision Process for Verizon:* Sunil and Williams-VZ outlined Verizon’s plan to review the provided proposals, compare with existing Adobe assets, and conduct internal discussions regarding business case justification and funding, with Adobe offering support for business case development and follow-up in January.
• *Internal Review and Comparison:* Sunil stated that the Verizon team will review the provided pricing and feature slides, compare the proposed AEM Forms solution with existing Adobe assets already in use by Williams-VZ’s team, and determine which approach best fits their use case.
• *Business Case and Funding Considerations:* The team discussed the need to prepare a business case and secure funding for the proposed solution, with Sunil noting that the internal process will determine the channel and structure for funding, and that Adobe’s Digital Services group can assist with business case development at no cost.
• *Timeline for Follow-Up:* It was agreed that, due to the holiday period, the Verizon team will reconvene internally and plan to reconnect with Adobe in the second week of January to discuss next steps and any further questions.

• *XFT to Adaptive Forms Migration Process:* Paul provided Vijay Kumar, Sudhanshu, and Satya Deep with a comprehensive overview of the migration process from legacy XFT forms to adaptive forms for the State of Washington project, detailing the technical workflow, challenges, and the use of custom utilities and scripts.
• *Legacy System Overview:* Paul explained that the original system consisted of approximately 300 XFT forms created in a VB application called Forms Gen, which interacted with various backend systems and produced both input and output forms, with output forms being archived and printed for different outlets.
• *Migration Workflow and Tools:* The migration involves parsing XFT files using a custom Python script to extract fields, properties, and embedded VBScript logic, which are then compiled into a specification spreadsheet that forms the basis for adaptive form development.
• *Reusable Components and Theming:* Paul described the creation of reusable fragments for common elements such as names and addresses, the development of a common theme and template, and the use of client libraries and custom layouts to standardize and streamline adaptive form creation.
• *Output Form Generation and Packaging:* The process includes assembling document packages by combining adaptive forms with output templates (XDPs), leveraging assembler APIs, and integrating third-party libraries for PDF handling and redaction, with the final packages distributed or archived as required.
• *Specification and QA Process:* A detailed specification document is generated for each form, reviewed and approved by the client, and used as a reference for both development and QA, ensuring alignment and traceability throughout the migration.
• *Project Scale, Timelines, and Resource Allocation:* Vijay Kumar and Sudhanshu inquired about the overall scale, batch processing, and time estimates for form migration, with Paul clarifying the number of forms, batching strategy, and the breakdown of effort between adaptive and output forms.
• *Form Volume and Batching:* Paul stated that the project involves migrating approximately 300 input forms and 800 output forms, with work proceeding in batches of five to ten forms at a time, and the current contract targeting around 100 adaptive forms.
• *Time Estimates and Workflow:* The typical timeline for creating an adaptive form is two to four weeks, depending on complexity, with the process including specification generation, client review, and development, while output templates are generally simpler and can be created in a day.
• *Effort Distribution:* Paul explained that adaptive form development usually takes one to five weeks per form for a developer, while output template creation is much faster due to their static and repetitive nature, and that work on output forms can begin in parallel with adaptive form specification review.
• *Reuse and Efficiency Gains:* The team leverages existing forms and fragments to accelerate development, often modifying similar forms rather than starting from scratch, which reduces effort and increases velocity as the project progresses.

• *Challenges with Legacy Code:* Despite automation efforts, significant variation in legacy VBScript and form logic limits the extent of automation, requiring manual review and interpretation, especially for unique or complex cases.

• *Project Management and Tracking:* The team uses two Jira systems—one internal and one customer-facing—for tracking development tasks and QA findings, with the project built using Maven, VS Code, and GitHub for version control and deployment.
